awd_titl_txt: The Study of Radiative Effects on Turbulent High Energy Density Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to learn whether or not a turbulent state can be created and understood in a laboratory high energy density plasma. High-energy-density (HED) plasmas, a hot soup of electrons, ions and photons, exist throughout our universe in an extreme state with high temperatures of over 10,000 K and very high densities. HED astrophysical systems include accretion phenomena, supernovae remnants, and supersonic outflows or jets, to name a few.  On the astrophysical scales, such as in supernovae, HED plasma systems can be thousands of miles in size.  In the laboratory, in a fusion experiment for example, an HED plasma can be one tenth of a centimeter. This study will investigate the impacts of the strong radiation carried by photons in a laboratory-sized HED plasma on the properties of complex fluid-like turbulence typical of plasmas at lower pressures and densities.  Better understanding of this fundamental behavior in laboratory-sized plasmas can inform understanding of HED plasmas in general.  

The aim of this work is to investigate the effect of radiation on late-time, multi-mode hydrodynamics of an HED plasma using an integrated approach combining theory, computation and experiments. To do so, first, a late-time, hydrodynamically unstable system will be created and observed. This will be accomplished by measuring the dependence of the unstable growth of density variations and multimode perturbations, using techniques developed by the team for ongoing experiments at the National Ignition Facility and the Omega Laser Facility. These measurements will enable validation of multidimensional radiation hydrodynamics codes to design an experiment that explores the effect of radiation on the evolution of late-time hydrodynamic processes.

por.por_cntn:
Radiative shocks are an active area of study in high-energy-density physics and are of importance in understanding a variety of astrophysical systems. A radiative shock occurs when the velocity of a shock is large enough that the material energy fluxes flowing into the shock create large radiation energy fluxes, the shock is not able to sustain these temperatures due to conservation of energy and must change structure to relax to a lower temperature final state. This is accomplished through the formation of an optically thin cooling layer at the density discontinuity, which acts to cool the inflowing material and heats the unshocked material. This type of behavior is the result of a radiative shock where the radiation produced at the shock front affects the structure of the shock with the exact details of the structure dependent on the opacity in the shocked and unshocked regions.

In recent experiments at the National Ignition Facility we used a half-hohlraum to drive a radiative shock into a 20 mg cm−3 plastic foam while making streaked self-emission and x-ray Thomson scattering measurements. Our data produced the first measurement of the radiative shock cooling rate in the laboratory. The self-emission data provided measurements of the shock trajectory, which when combined with an one-dimensional model of shocks with an optically thick post-shock region and optically thin pre-shock region provided a quite detailed characterization of the shock conditions. We found that the shock had an average velocity of 133.9 +/-  8.3 um ns−1, peak temperature of 50.9 +/- 3 eV, and a compression of 9.1+/- 0.7. We also found the presence of preheating of the foam material very shortly after the lasers turn on producing an initial temperature of 8.4 +/-  0.5 eV and an ionization of 1.35 +/-  0.06. The scattering measurements agree with the self-emission results.
